WA Constitution Article VII; capital gains tax classified as excise tax

Avg income $18,600; down from 17.8% in prior edition
Avg income $2,077,500; up from 3% pre-capital gains tax
Lowest earners pay 3.4x the effective rate of top 1%

3A.data_point: WA universal healthcare estimated annual cost range
3A.source_name: WA Universal Health Care Commission / HCA
3A.notes: Range depending on benefit package; replaces all current spending

3A.value: Latest commission report with cost modeling updates
3A.notes: Includes FTAC analysis and transition models

3A.data_point: Milliman actuarial cost analysis for WA universal HC
3A.value: Modeled 3 scenarios: Medicaid-like, PEBB-like, Cascade Care Silver
3A.notes: Independent actuarial analysis commissioned by HCA

3A.value: Official commission homepage with all documents
Commission plotting pathway to universal system

3A.data_point: Key note: cost replaces existing spending
3A.value: Universal HC would replace current private+public spending, not add to it; requires new tax funding to replace premiums
3A.notes: Critical for simulator: net new funding = total cost minus current public spending
Most recent state-level CMS data; 2020 baseline

3A.data_point: US national per capita health spending
WA estimated total healthcare spending (all payers)
3A.notes: Rough estimate: $10,989 (2020) adjusted for growth x 7.96M pop; exact figure in HCA reports

3A.data_point: WA Health Care Cost Transparency Board 2024 report
3A.value: Total health care expenditure tracking and benchmarks

3A.notes: Data call report with growth analysis

3A.value: Interactive tool for spending by payer, state

3B.value: Up to 75% of state median income ($76,626/yr for family of 3)

3B.notes: ~27% avg statewide increase to cost-of-quality rates

3B.data_point: Only ~29% of children needing care served by licensed providers

3B.notes: Full-time center-based for all; actual would be lower with enrollment rates
